question: What variables and cutoffs are used in the Alvarado score for suspected appendicitis?
response:
Alvarado score (MANTRELS), max 10 points:
- Migration of pain to right lower quadrant (1)
- Anorexia (1)
- Nausea/vomiting (1)
- Right lower quadrant tenderness (2)
- Rebound tenderness (1)
- Fever >37.3°C/99.1°F (1)
- Leukocytosis >10,000/µL (2)
- Left shift (neutrophils >75%) (1). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10413131/?utm_source=openai))

Common score cutoffs for suspected appendicitis:
- 1–4: low likelihood
- 5–6: compatible; observe/imaging
- ≥7: probable; surgical consult/consider surgery. ([bmcmedicine.biomedcentral.com](https://bmcmedicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1741-7015-9-139?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10413131/
https://journals.lww.com/md-journal/fulltext/2023/04250/does_one_of_the_two_most_commonly_used_scoring.31.aspx
https://bmcmedicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1741-7015-9-139

question: What variables and cutoffs are used in the Alvarado score for suspected appendicitis?
response:
Alvarado score (MANTRELS) variables and points (max 10):
- Migration of pain to right lower quadrant: 1
- Anorexia: 1
- Nausea/vomiting: 1
- Right lower quadrant tenderness: 2
- Rebound tenderness: 1
- Elevated temperature (fever): 1
- Leukocytosis: 2
- Left shift of neutrophils: 1

Common cutoffs/interpretation:
- Low risk: 1–4 (useful to rule out; <5 has high sensitivity to exclude appendicitis)
- Intermediate: 5–6 (observe and/or image)
- High risk: ≥7 (suggests appendicitis; some guidelines consider ≥9 very high probability)

These thresholds are widely used; evidence supports <5 to rule out and ≥7 to rule in with caution, as specificity varies by population. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK493193/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK493193/
https://bestpractice.bmj.com/topics/en-us/290/diagnosis-approach
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22204638/

question: What variables and cutoffs are used in the Alvarado score for suspected appendicitis?
response:
Variables (points): migration to RLQ (1); anorexia/ketonuria (1); nausea/vomiting (1); RLQ tenderness (2); rebound pain (1); fever ≥37.3°C (1); leukocytosis >10,000/mm³ (2); left shift/neutrophils ≥75% (1). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4214266/?utm_source=openai))

Cutoffs: score <5 helps rule out appendicitis; score ≥7 suggests appendicitis and commonly prompts surgical consultation/operation. ([bmcmedicine.biomedcentral.com](https://bmcmedicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1741-7015-9-139?utm_source=openai))

Source relevance: The peer‑reviewed review reproduces the original Alvarado variables with numeric thresholds, and the systematic review evaluates performance specifically at the <5 and ≥7 decision cut points. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4214266/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4214266/
https://bmcmedicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1741-7015-9-139

question: What variables and cutoffs are used in the Alvarado score for suspected appendicitis?
response:
Alvarado score (MANTRELS), max 10 points:
- Migration of pain to right lower quadrant: 1
- Anorexia: 1
- Nausea/vomiting: 1
- Right lower quadrant tenderness: 2
- Rebound pain: 1
- Elevated temperature (fever): 1
- Leukocytosis (>10,000/μL): 2
- Left shift (neutrophilia): 1. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK355447/table/results.t13/?utm_source=openai))

Common cutoffs:
- <5: low probability; often suitable for rule-out/observation.
- 5–6: equivocal/intermediate; consider imaging/observation.
- ≥7: high probability; prompt surgical evaluation is typical. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22204638/?utm_source=openai))

Some guidance stratifies risk as 0–4 low, 5–8 intermediate, and 9–10 high. ([bestpractice.bmj.com](https://bestpractice.bmj.com/topics/en-us/290/diagnosis-approach?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK355447/table/results.t13/
https://bmcmedicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1741-7015-9-139
https://bestpractice.bmj.com/topics/en-us/290/diagnosis-approach

question: What severity grades and criteria are defined by the Tokyo Guidelines for acute cholecystitis?
response:
Tokyo Guidelines grade acute cholecystitis as:
- Grade III (severe): Organ dysfunction in any one system—cardiovascular (hypotension requiring dopamine ≥5 μg/kg/min or any norepinephrine), neurologic (decreased consciousness), respiratory (PaO2/FiO2 <300), renal (oliguria or creatinine >2.0 mg/dL), hepatic (INR >1.5), or hematologic (platelets <100,000/mm3). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3429769/?utm_source=openai))
- Grade II (moderate): Any one of—WBC >18,000/μL; palpable tender right‑upper‑quadrant mass; symptoms >72 h; marked local inflammation (gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic/hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3429769/?utm_source=openai))
- Grade I (mild): Does not meet Grade II or III criteria (typically no organ dysfunction and only mild gallbladder inflammation). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3429769/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3429769/
https://bmcsurg.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12893-017-0319-6/tables/1
https://bmcgastroenterol.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12876-017-0631-8/tables/1

question: What severity grades and criteria are defined by the Tokyo Guidelines for acute cholecystitis?
response:
Tokyo Guidelines (TG13; adopted unchanged in TG18) grade acute cholecystitis as: ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29032636/?utm_source=openai))
- Grade I (mild): no organ dysfunction; does not meet Grade II/III.
- Grade II (moderate): any of the following: WBC >18,000/μL; palpable tender RUQ mass; symptoms >72 h; marked local inflammation (gangrenous/emphysematous cholecystitis; pericholecystic or hepatic abscess; biliary peritonitis).
- Grade III (severe): organ dysfunction in any one system: cardiovascular (hypotension requiring dopamine ≥5 μg/kg/min or any norepinephrine); neurologic (decreased consciousness); respiratory (PaO2/FiO2 <300); renal (oliguria or creatinine >2.0 mg/dL); hepatic (PT-INR >1.5); hematologic (platelets <100,000/μL). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3429769/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29032636/
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3429769/

question: What severity grades and criteria are defined by the Tokyo Guidelines for acute cholecystitis?
response:
Tokyo Guidelines severity grades for acute cholecystitis:
- Grade III (severe): Organ dysfunction in any one system—cardiovascular (hypotension requiring dopamine ≥5 μg/kg/min or any norepinephrine), neurological (decreased consciousness), respiratory (PaO2/FiO2 <300), renal (oliguria or creatinine >2.0 mg/dL), hepatic (PT-INR >1.5), or hematologic (platelets <100,000/μL). 
- Grade II (moderate): Any one of—WBC >18,000/μL; palpable tender right-upper-quadrant mass; duration of symptoms >72 hours; marked local inflammation (e.g., gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic/hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis). 
- Grade I (mild): Does not meet Grade II or III criteria (no organ dysfunction; mild local inflammation).

These sources present the TG13/TG18 severity definitions and explicit thresholds/tables used in current practice.

Sources:
https://www.jshbps.jp/modules/en/index.php?content_id=47
https://www.mdpi.com/2077-0383/12/14/4711
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10533096/
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11916569/

question: What severity grades and criteria are defined by the Tokyo Guidelines for acute cholecystitis?
response:
Tokyo Guidelines (TG13; unchanged in TG18) classify acute cholecystitis into three grades:

- Grade III (severe): Organ dysfunction in any one system
  - Cardiovascular: hypotension requiring dopamine ≥5 μg/kg/min or any norepinephrine
  - Neurologic: decreased level of consciousness
  - Respiratory: PaO2/FiO2 < 300
  - Renal: oliguria or creatinine > 2.0 mg/dL
  - Hepatic: PT-INR > 1.5
  - Hematologic: platelets < 100,000/μL

- Grade II (moderate): Any of
  - WBC > 18,000/μL
  - Palpable tender right‑upper‑quadrant mass
  - Symptoms > 72 hours
  - Marked local inflammation (e.g., gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic/hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis)

- Grade I (mild): Does not meet Grade II or III criteria.

Sources:
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3429769/
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29032636/
https://bmcgastroenterol.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12876-017-0631-8/tables/1

question: What imaging findings define a positive FAST exam in blunt abdominal trauma?
response:
Positive FAST = visualization of free fluid in any standard FAST window in a trauma patient.

- RUQ: Anechoic fluid in the hepatorenal recess (Morison’s pouch), caudal liver tip/right paracolic gutter, or hepato-diaphragmatic space. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470479/?utm_source=openai))
- LUQ: Anechoic fluid in the splenorenal recess or perisplenic/subphrenic space. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470479/?utm_source=openai))
- Pelvis: Anechoic fluid posterior/superior to the bladder (rectovesical pouch in males; rectouterine pouch/Pouch of Douglas in females). Any amount in trauma context is considered positive (physiologic small pelvic fluid can occur in reproductive-age females). ([journals.lww.com](https://journals.lww.com/jmut/fulltext/2023/31020/focused_assessment_with_sonography_for_trauma.4.aspx?utm_source=openai))
- Pericardial view: Anechoic pericardial effusion consistent with hemopericardium. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470479/?utm_source=openai))

In short, any sonographic free fluid in peritoneal or pericardial spaces constitutes a positive FAST in blunt abdominal trauma. ([journals.lww.com](https://journals.lww.com/10.4103/IJCIIS.IJCIIS_7_17?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.acep.org/sonoguide/basic/fast
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470479/
https://journals.lww.com/10.4103/IJCIIS.IJCIIS_7_17
https://www.acep.org/emultrasound/newsroom/jul2021/cases-that-count-serial-fast-examinations-in-a-patient-with-a-penetrating-stab-wound-to-the-buttock

question: What imaging findings define a positive FAST exam in blunt abdominal trauma?
response:
Positive FAST = visualization of free fluid on ultrasound (anechoic or hypoechoic) in any dependent potential space:
- RUQ: hepatorenal recess (Morison’s pouch), caudal tip/perihepatic region.
- LUQ: perisplenic/subdiaphragmatic spaces (± splenorenal recess).
- Pelvis: posterior to the bladder (rectovesical space in males) or in the rectouterine pouch/Pouch of Douglas (and vesicouterine pouch) in females.
- Cardiac (part of FAST): anechoic fluid in the pericardial sac on subxiphoid view (hemopericardium).

In trauma, such free fluid is presumed blood unless another cause is evident; note that a trace of pelvic fluid can be physiologic in reproductive‑age women.

Sources:
https://www.acep.org/sonoguide/basic/fast
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470479/
https://r3journal.arrs.org/acute-abdomen-point-of-care-ultrasound/

question: What imaging findings define a positive FAST exam in blunt abdominal trauma?
response:
Positive FAST is defined by ultrasound visualization of free fluid (typically anechoic) in dependent intraperitoneal spaces—RUQ (Morrison’s pouch/right paracolic/hepato‑diaphragmatic), LUQ (splenorenal/subphrenic/left paracolic), pelvis (rectovesical or rectouterine)—and/or pericardial effusion. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470479/?utm_source=openai))

Source relevance: ACEP Sonoguide and StatPearls are authoritative emergency ultrasound references that explicitly define FAST positivity and list the dependent spaces where fluid is sought. ([acep.org](https://www.acep.org/sonoguide/basic/fast?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.acep.org/sonoguide/basic/fast
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470479/

question: What imaging findings define a positive FAST exam in blunt abdominal trauma?
response:
Positive FAST = sonographic free fluid.

- Intraperitoneal: anechoic or hypoechoic fluid in any dependent space on standard views—RUQ (Morison’s pouch/hepatorenal recess/right paracolic gutter), LUQ (splenorenal recess/subdiaphragmatic), or pelvis (rectovesical/rectouterine pouch). Solid-organ injury visualization is not required. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8933745/?utm_source=openai))
- Pericardial: anechoic pericardial effusion on the subxiphoid or parasternal cardiac view. Trace pelvic fluid may still be considered positive in trauma; clotted blood can appear heterogeneous. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8933745/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8933745/
https://www.acep.org/emultrasound/newsroom/jul2021/cases-that-count-serial-fast-examinations-in-a-patient-with-a-penetrating-stab-wound-to-the-buttock
https://www.acep.org/sonoguide/procedures/pericardiocentesis/

question: What ECG patterns and clinical context define Wellens syndrome (types A and B)?
response:
Definition/clinical context:
- Pain-free patient after recent angina with minimal/normal troponin.
- ECG during pain-free period shows: preserved precordial R-wave progression, no precordial Q waves, and isoelectric or <1 mm ST elevation (usually in V2–V3). Strongly suggests critical proximal LAD stenosis and high short‑term risk of anterior MI; avoid stress testing, pursue urgent angiography. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK482490/?utm_source=openai))

ECG patterns:
- Type A (≈25%): biphasic T waves in V2–V3 with initial positivity and terminal negativity; may extend V1–V6. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK482490/?utm_source=openai))
- Type B (≈75%): deep, symmetric T‑wave inversions in V2–V3 (can involve other precordial leads). ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK482490/?utm_source=openai))

These patterns are typically recorded when pain-free and may “pseudonormalize” during pain. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK482490/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK482490/
https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/
https://journals.lww.com/jaapa/Fulltext/2023/02000/Wellens_syndrome__An_important_consideration_in.5.aspx

question: What ECG patterns and clinical context define Wellens syndrome (types A and B)?
response:
Wellens syndrome is a pre-infarction ECG pattern signaling critical proximal LAD stenosis.

ECG (captured when pain-free after recent angina):
- Type A: biphasic T waves (initial positive, terminal negative) in V2–V3; may extend V1–V6; about 25% of cases.
- Type B: deep, symmetric T‑wave inversion in V2–V3; about 75% of cases.

Additional criteria/context: minimal or no ST deviation (isoelectric or <1 mm elevation, sometimes slight depression), no precordial Q waves, preserved R‑wave progression, and normal or only mildly elevated troponin. Patients are at high risk of imminent large anterior MI; avoid stress testing and pursue urgent cardiology evaluation/revascularization.

Sources:
https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2023/01/20/17/59/wellens-syndrome
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK482490/

question: What ECG patterns and clinical context define Wellens syndrome (types A and B)?
response:
Definition/context: Pain-free after recent angina, with normal or mildly elevated troponin, indicating critical proximal LAD stenosis and high risk of anterior MI. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))
ECG patterns:
- Type A: biphasic T waves (initial up then down) in V2–V3. ([acc.org](https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2023/01/20/17/59/wellens-syndrome))
- Type B: deep, symmetric T‑wave inversions in V2–V3. ([acc.org](https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2023/01/20/17/59/wellens-syndrome))
Additional ECG criteria: changes often extend V1–V6; ST is isoelectric or minimally changed (<1 mm); preserved R‑wave progression; no precordial Q waves; pattern appears when pain‑free. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))

Why these sources: ACC, StatPearls, and LITFL provide society‑vetted or peer‑reviewed descriptions of the Wellens ECG patterns and clinical context.

Sources:
https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/
https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2023/01/20/17/59/wellens-syndrome
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482490/

question: What ECG patterns and clinical context define Wellens syndrome (types A and B)?
response:
Wellens syndrome is a pre-infarction pattern seen after chest pain resolves, highly specific for critical proximal LAD stenosis. Clinical context: pain-free at ECG, recent angina, normal or slightly elevated troponin; ECG shows isoelectric or minimal ST elevation (<1 mm), preserved R-wave progression, and no precordial Q waves. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))

ECG patterns
- Type A (~25%): biphasic T waves in V2–V3 (initial positive, terminal negative).
- Type B (~75%): deeply symmetric T-wave inversion in V2–V3 (may extend V1–V6).
Changes are classically recorded in the pain-free state and may “pseudonormalize” during pain. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482490/

question: What are the diagnostic criteria for takotsubo cardiomyopathy?
response:
Two commonly used criteria sets:

Modified Mayo Clinic criteria (2008) — all required:
- Transient LV regional wall‑motion abnormalities (often beyond a single coronary territory, ± apical involvement).
- No obstructive coronary disease or angiographic evidence of acute plaque rupture.
- New ECG changes (ST elevation/T‑wave inversion) or modest troponin rise.
- No pheochromocytoma or myocarditis. ([jstage.jst.go.jp](https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/circj/78/9/78_CJ-14-0859/_article))

InterTAK Diagnostic Criteria (2018) — key elements:
- Transient LV dysfunction with typical patterns (apical, mid‑ventricular, basal, or focal); RV involvement possible.
- Trigger (emotional/physical) may be present but is not mandatory; neurological disorders or pheochromocytoma can act as triggers.
- New ECG abnormalities and moderate biomarker elevation (troponin; BNP often high).
- Significant coronary artery disease can co‑exist but should not explain dysfunction.
- Exclude infectious myocarditis; predominance in postmenopausal women. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/circj/78/9/78_CJ-14-0859/_article
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412

question: What are the diagnostic criteria for takotsubo cardiomyopathy?
response:
Most current: InterTAK Diagnostic Criteria (2018). Diagnose takotsubo syndrome when the following are considered:
- Transient LV systolic dysfunction (apical, midventricular, basal or focal), usually beyond a single coronary territory; RV may be involved.
- Emotional/physical trigger may precede (not required); neurologic disease or pheochromocytoma can be triggers.
- New ECG changes (ST elevation/depression, T‑wave inversion, QTc prolongation).
- Cardiac biomarkers modestly elevated; BNP often high.
- Coronary artery disease may coexist (no culprit thrombotic occlusion).
- No infectious myocarditis (CMR recommended to exclude).
- Predominantly affects postmenopausal women.
Coronary angiography with LV imaging is the gold standard to exclude ACS and confirm TTS. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412))

Sources:
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412
https://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/articles/2018/06/21/12/42/feature-story-takotsubo-syndrome-key-points-to-remember-to-improve-practice

question: What are the diagnostic criteria for takotsubo cardiomyopathy?
response:
Diagnostic criteria (InterTAK, 2018):
- Transient LV dysfunction with typical wall‑motion patterns (apical, midventricular, basal, or focal); RV may be involved; abnormalities usually extend beyond one vascular territory. 
- Emotional/physical trigger may occur but is not required.
- Neurologic disorders or pheochromocytoma can be triggers.
- New ECG changes (ST elevation/depression, T‑wave inversion, QTc prolongation); occasionally none.
- Cardiac biomarkers moderately elevated; BNP often markedly elevated.
- Significant coronary artery disease may coexist (not exclusionary).
- No evidence of infectious myocarditis (CMR recommended to exclude).
- Predominantly affects postmenopausal women. 
Earlier “revised Mayo” criteria emphasize transient wall‑motion abnormality beyond one vascular territory, absence of obstructive CAD/plaque rupture, new ECG changes or modest troponin rise, and exclusion of pheochromocytoma/myocarditis.

Source relevance: The 2018 European Heart Journal international consensus defines InterTAK criteria; the takotsubo.net page reproduces the full table and HFA criteria, and the Circulation Journal article details the widely used revised Mayo criteria.

Sources:
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412
https://takotsubo.net/health-professionals/diagnosing-takotsubo/
https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/circj/78/9/78_CJ-14-0859/_article

question: What are the diagnostic criteria for takotsubo cardiomyopathy?
response:
Two commonly used criteria:

- Revised Mayo Clinic criteria (2008): (1) Transient LV regional wall‑motion abnormality beyond a single epicardial territory (often apical); (2) No obstructive coronary disease or acute plaque rupture; (3) New ECG changes (ST elevation and/or T‑wave inversion) or modest troponin rise; (4) Absence of pheochromocytoma and myocarditis. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK430798/))

- InterTAK Diagnostic Criteria (2018 consensus): (1) Transient LV dysfunction with apical, mid‑ventricular, basal, or focal patterns; RV involvement possible; (2) Emotional/physical trigger common but not required; (3) Neurologic disease or pheochromocytoma may be triggers; (4) New ECG changes, including QTc prolongation; (5) Troponin/CK modestly elevated; BNP often high; (6) Significant CAD may coexist (not exclusion); (7) No infectious myocarditis; (8) Predominantly postmenopausal women; CMR recommended to exclude myocarditis. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5991216/))

Sources:
- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK430798/
- https://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2020/03/30/12/17/takotsubo-syndrome
- https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5991216/

question: What major and minor criteria diagnose infective endocarditis?
response:
Major criteria (Duke/Duke‑ISCVID 2023)
- Microbiologic: typical IE organisms from ≥2 blood‑culture sets or persistently positive cultures; single positive for Coxiella burnetii (phase I IgG ≥1:800); pathogen ID for C. burnetii, Bartonella spp., or T. whipplei by PCR/NGS; Bartonella IgG ≥1:800. Typical organisms include oral streptococci, Streptococcus gallolyticus, HACEK, Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus faecalis.
- Imaging: evidence of endocardial involvement—vegetation, abscess, new partial prosthetic dehiscence, or new regurgitation on echo; characteristic lesions on cardiac CT, 18F‑FDG PET/CT, or WBC SPECT (especially prosthetic valves).
- Surgical: intraoperative macroscopic evidence of IE (2023 addition).

Minor criteria
- Predisposition (cardiac risk or injection drug use)
- Fever ≥38°C
- Vascular phenomena (systemic/pulmonary emboli or infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions; cerebral/splenic abscess)
- Immunologic phenomena (glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor)
- Microbiologic evidence not meeting major.

Sources:
https://academic.oup.com/cid/article-abstract/77/4/518/7151107
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/44/39/3948/7243107
https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/endocarditis/infective-endocarditis

question: What major and minor criteria diagnose infective endocarditis?
response:
Major (Modified Duke)
- Positive blood cultures with typical IE organisms (viridans streptococci, Streptococcus gallolyticus/bovis, HACEK, Staphylococcus aureus; community-acquired enterococci without another focus), with persistent positives; or a single positive for Coxiella burnetii or phase‑I IgG ≥1:800.
- Evidence of endocardial involvement: echocardiogram showing vegetation, abscess, or new partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve; or new valvular regurgitation.

Minor
- Predisposition (cardiac lesion or injection drug use).
- Fever ≥38°C.
- Vascular phenomena (arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions).
- Immunologic phenomena (glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor).
- Microbiologic evidence not meeting major.

Diagnostic thresholds: Definite IE = 2 major, or 1 major + 3 minor, or 5 minor. Note: 2023 Duke‑ISCVID updates add PET/CT, cardiac CT, and intraoperative surgical findings as Major in appropriate settings, and refine organism lists.

Sources:
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article-abstract/36/44/3075/2293384
https://academic.oup.com/cid/article-abstract/77/4/518/7151107

question: What major and minor criteria diagnose infective endocarditis?
response:
Major (Duke‑ISCVID 2023): 
- Microbiology: ≥2 positive blood‑culture sets for typical IE organisms (or ≥3 for less typical), or PCR/serology for Coxiella, Bartonella, or T. whipplei. 
- Imaging/surgery: Echo/cardiac CT showing vegetation, abscess, perforation/fistula, prosthetic partial dehiscence, or significant new regurgitation; [18F]-FDG PET/CT uptake on valves/leads/prostheses ≥3 months after valve implantation; or intraoperative evidence of IE. 
Minor: 
- Predisposition (prosthetic/transcatheter valves, CIEDs, prior IE, congenital disease, significant valve disease/HOCM, or IVDU); fever ≥38°C; vascular phenomena (arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhage, Janeway lesions, brain/splenic abscess, purulent purpura); immunologic phenomena (GN, Osler nodes, Roth spots, RF); microbiologic evidence not meeting major; PET/CT uptake <3 months after valve implantation; auscultatory new regurgitation if echo unavailable. 

These sources reproduce and originate the 2023 Duke‑ISCVID criteria, the current reference standard.

Sources:
https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/endocarditis/infective-endocarditis
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37138445/

question: What major and minor criteria diagnose infective endocarditis?
response:
Most current: 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria.

Major
- Microbiologic: Typical IE organisms from ≥2 blood-culture sets; or nontypical from ≥3; or PCR/serology for Coxiella, Bartonella, or Tropheryma whipplei (single positive for C. burnetii or Bartonella IFA ≥1:800 accepted). 
- Imaging: Echo or cardiac CT showing vegetation/abscess/perforation/pseudoaneurysm/fistula, new prosthetic dehiscence, or new regurgitation; or abnormal FDG-PET/CT involving valve/graft/CIED.
- Surgical: Intraoperative direct evidence of IE. ([journalfeed.org](https://journalfeed.org/article-a-day/2024/what-are-the-new-duke-iscvid-criteria/))

Minor
- Predisposition (prior IE, prosthetic valve/repair, CHD, significant valve disease, CIED, HOCM, injection drug use); fever ≥38°C; vascular phenomena (emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, cerebral/splenic abscess, mycotic aneurysm, ICH, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway); immunologic phenomena (RF, Osler nodes, Roth spots, immune-complex GN); microbiology not meeting major; select imaging/auscultation findings when echo unavailable. ([journalfeed.org](https://journalfeed.org/article-a-day/2024/what-are-the-new-duke-iscvid-criteria/))

Definite IE: 2 major; or 1 major + 3 minor; or 5 minor. ([journalfeed.org](https://journalfeed.org/article-a-day/2024/what-are-the-new-duke-iscvid-criteria/))
Sources:
https://journalfeed.org/article-a-day/2024/what-are-the-new-duke-iscvid-criteria/
https://academic.oup.com/cid/article-abstract/77/4/518/7151107
https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2023/08/29/20/49/2023-esc-guidelines-for-endocarditis-esc-2023

question: What clinical and laboratory criteria define sepsis and septic shock (Sepsis-3)?
response:
- Sepsis (Sepsis-3): Life-threatening organ dysfunction from infection, operationalized as suspected/documented infection plus an acute increase in SOFA score ≥2 points (organs assessed include respiratory, coagulation, liver, cardiovascular, CNS, and renal). qSOFA (RR ≥22/min, SBP ≤100 mmHg, altered mentation): ≥2 flags high risk and prompts evaluation for organ dysfunction. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4968574/?utm_source=openai))
- Septic shock: Sepsis with persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg and serum lactate >2 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492876?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4968574/
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492876
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492875
https://www.sccm.org/clinical-resources/sepsis-definitions

question: What clinical and laboratory criteria define sepsis and septic shock (Sepsis-3)?
response:
- Sepsis (Sepsis-3): Suspected or documented infection plus life-threatening organ dysfunction, operationalized as an acute increase in SOFA score ≥2 points from baseline. SOFA components: PaO2/FiO2, platelets, bilirubin, MAP/vasopressors, Glasgow Coma Scale, creatinine/urine output. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881?utm_source=openai))
- qSOFA (screening tool, not diagnostic): ≥2 of respiratory rate ≥22/min, systolic BP ≤100 mm Hg, or altered mentation → prompts SOFA assessment and escalation. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881?utm_source=openai))
- Septic shock: Sepsis with persisting hypotension requiring vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mm Hg AND serum lactate >2 mmol/L (>18 mg/dL) despite adequate fluid resuscitation, in the absence of hypovolemia. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881
https://www.sccm.org/clinical-resources/sepsis-definitions

question: What clinical and laboratory criteria define sepsis and septic shock (Sepsis-3)?
response:
- Sepsis (Sepsis-3): Suspected or documented infection with life‑threatening organ dysfunction, operationalized as an acute increase in SOFA score ≥2 points. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881))
- Septic shock (Sepsis-3): Sepsis plus persisting hypotension requiring vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mm Hg and serum lactate >2 mmol/L (18 mg/dL) despite adequate fluid resuscitation (i.e., not due to hypovolemia). ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881))

Why this source: It is the original 2016 JAMA Sepsis‑3 consensus paper that defines sepsis and septic shock and specifies the SOFA and vasopressor/lactate criteria used worldwide. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881))

Sources:
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881

question: What clinical and laboratory criteria define sepsis and septic shock (Sepsis-3)?
response:
- Sepsis (Sepsis-3): Suspected or documented infection plus acute organ dysfunction, operationalized as an acute increase in SOFA score ≥2 points from baseline (SOFA uses clinical/lab variables: PaO2/FiO2, platelets, bilirubin, MAP/vasopressors, Glasgow Coma Scale, creatinine/urine output). This threshold carries ~10% in-hospital mortality. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881))

- Septic shock: Sepsis with persisting hypotension requiring vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mm Hg and serum lactate >2 mmol/L (18 mg/dL) despite adequate volume resuscitation; mortality typically exceeds 40%. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881))

Note: qSOFA (RR ≥22/min, SBP ≤100 mm Hg, altered mentation) is a bedside prompt, not diagnostic; guidelines advise against using qSOFA alone for screening. ([sccm.org](https://sccm.org/clinical-resources/guidelines/guidelines/surviving-sepsis-guidelines-2021?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881
https://www.sccm.org/Clinical-Resources/Guidelines/Guidelines/Surviving-Sepsis-Guidelines-2021

question: What pre-exposure and post-exposure prophylaxis regimens exist for HIV, and what baseline labs are required?
response:
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)
- Regimens: daily oral TDF/FTC; daily oral TAF/FTC (not for receptive vaginal sex); long‑acting cabotegravir IM (day 0, month 1, then every 2 months). Off‑label “2‑1‑1” TDF/FTC for adult MSM has evidence but isn’t CDC‑recommended.
- Baseline labs: HIV Ag/Ab (add HIV‑1 RNA if acute symptoms/recent PrEP/PEP), STI tests (gonorrhea/chlamydia NAATs, syphilis), renal function/eCrCl (>60 mL/min for TDF; ≥30 for TAF), hepatitis B serologies (HBsAg, anti‑HBc, anti‑HBs), lipid panel if using TAF. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/prep/index.html))

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)
- When and how: start ASAP and ≤72 hours; treat for 28 days.
- Preferred adult/adolescent regimens (CDC 2025): BIC/FTC/TAF once daily; or DTG + (TAF or TDF) + (FTC or 3TC). ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/74/rr/rr7401a1.htm?utm_source=openai))
- Baseline labs: rapid HIV test (start PEP immediately if testing unavailable), pregnancy test when relevant, creatinine/BUN, liver enzymes, hepatitis B panel, hepatitis C antibody, and STI testing for sexual exposures. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/pep/index.html?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/prep/index.html
https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/prevention/prep.html
https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/74/rr/rr7401a1.htm
https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/pep/index.html

question: What pre-exposure and post-exposure prophylaxis regimens exist for HIV, and what baseline labs are required?
response:
PrEP (pre‑exposure):
- Daily oral TDF/FTC (all sexual exposures and injection drug use).
- Daily oral TAF/FTC (not for receptive vaginal sex).
- Long‑acting cabotegravir 600 mg IM: start, again at 1 month, then every 2 months.
- Lenacapavir SC every 6 months (FDA‑approved 2025; CDC recommends as a PrEP option).
- Event‑driven “2‑1‑1” TDF/FTC for adult MSM only; off‑label and not CDC‑recommended but may be prescribed in select MSM.

PEP (post‑exposure): 28 days, start ≤72 hours.
- Preferred: TDF/FTC + raltegravir or dolutegravir.
- Alternative: TDF/FTC + darunavir/ritonavir.

Baseline labs
- PrEP: HIV Ag/Ab (± HIV‑1 RNA if recent ARVs/symptoms), STI screening, creatinine/eCrCl for oral tenofovir, HBV serology (HBsAg, anti‑HBs, anti‑HBc); lipid panel if using TAF/FTC.
- PEP: Baseline HIV rapid test; pregnancy test if applicable; LFTs; BUN/creatinine; STI tests; HBV panel; HCV antibody.

Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/prep/index.html
https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/pep/index.html
https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/74/wr/mm7435a1.htm

question: What pre-exposure and post-exposure prophylaxis regimens exist for HIV, and what baseline labs are required?
response:
PrEP regimens (U.S., 2025): daily oral TDF/FTC; daily oral TAF/FTC (not for receptive vaginal sex); cabotegravir LA IM after a 1‑month second dose then every 2 months; lenacapavir SC every 6 months. Event‑driven “2‑1‑1” TDF/FTC exists for adult MSM but is off‑label and not CDC‑recommended. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/prep/index.html?utm_source=openai))
Baseline labs for PrEP: confirm HIV‑negative with Ag/Ab testing (add HIV‑1 RNA if recent PrEP/PEP or acute symptoms), screen for STIs, assess kidney function for tenofovir regimens (eCrCl thresholds), HBV serology; check lipids if using TAF/FTC. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/prep/index.html?utm_source=openai))
PEP regimens: start within ≤72 hours for 28 days with either BIC/FTC/TAF or DTG + (TAF or TDF) + (FTC or 3TC); baseline labs include rapid HIV test, pregnancy test if applicable, LFTs, BUN/Cr, STI tests, and HBV/HCV serology. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/74/rr/rr7401a1.htm?utm_source=openai))

These sources are current CDC clinical guidance and 2025 MMWR updates, the primary U.S. recommendations.

Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/prep/index.html
https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/74/wr/mm7435a1.htm
https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/74/rr/rr7401a1.htm
https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/pep/index.html

question: What pre-exposure and post-exposure prophylaxis regimens exist for HIV, and what baseline labs are required?
response:
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)
- Daily oral TDF/FTC (all risk groups). 
- Daily oral TAF/FTC (not for receptive vaginal sex). 
- Long-acting cabotegravir 600 mg IM: day 0, 1 month, then every 2 months. 
- Lenacapavir (capsid inhibitor) SC every 6 months (FDA 6/18/2025). 
Baseline for PrEP: confirm HIV-negative (Ag/Ab; add HIV-1 RNA if symptoms/recent ARVs; for cabotegravir/lenacapavir obtain same-day Ag/Ab and RNA), renal function for oral tenofovir (eCrCl thresholds: TDF >60, TAF ≥30), HBV serology, STI screening, pregnancy test as applicable; lipids if using TAF. 

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)
- 28 days, start ASAP ≤72 hours: 
  - Preferred: BIC/FTC/TAF once daily, OR DTG + (TAF or TDF) + (FTC or 3TC). 
Baseline for PEP: HIV Ag/Ab (add HIV NAT if received long-acting PrEP in past 6 months), creatinine and AST/ALT, HBV and HCV testing, pregnancy test, STI testing. Do not delay first dose pending labs.

Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/74/rr/rr7401a1.htm
https://www.cdc.gov/hivnexus/hcp/prep/index.html
https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/74/wr/mm7435a1.htm

question: What components and cutoffs define the Ottawa ankle rules and Ottawa knee rules?
response:
Ottawa Ankle Rules
- Ankle series: Pain in malleolar zone AND either (a) bony tenderness at posterior edge/tip of lateral or medial malleolus (distal 6 cm), or (b) inability to bear weight 4 steps immediately and in the ED. ([aci.health.nsw.gov.au](https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-ankle-adult?utm_source=openai))
- Foot series: Pain in midfoot zone AND either (a) bony tenderness at base of 5th metatarsal or navicular, or (b) inability to bear weight 4 steps immediately and in the ED. ([aci.health.nsw.gov.au](https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-ankle-adult?utm_source=openai))

Ottawa Knee Rule (after acute knee trauma)
Order knee radiographs if ANY of:
- Age ≥55 years
- Isolated patellar tenderness
- Fibular head tenderness
- Inability to flex knee to 90°
- Inability to bear weight 4 steps immediately and in the ED. ([aci.health.nsw.gov.au](https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-knee?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-ankle-adult
https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-knee

question: What components and cutoffs define the Ottawa ankle rules and Ottawa knee rules?
response:
Ottawa Ankle/Foot Rules
- Ankle radiographs: pain in malleolar zone plus any of:
  - Tenderness at posterior edge or tip of lateral or medial malleolus within distal 6 cm; or
  - Inability to bear weight both immediately and in the ED (4 steps).
- Foot radiographs: pain in midfoot zone plus any of:
  - Tenderness at navicular; or
  - Tenderness at base of 5th metatarsal; or
  - Inability to bear weight both immediately and in the ED (4 steps). ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7912053/))

Ottawa Knee Rule (after acute knee injury)
- Knee radiographs if any of:
  - Age ≥55 years;
  - Isolated patellar tenderness;
  - Fibular head tenderness;
  - Inability to flex knee to 90°;
  - Inability to bear weight immediately and in the ED (4 steps). ([aci.health.nsw.gov.au](https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-knee?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7912053/
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/397187
https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-knee

- Ankle X‑ray: pain in malleolar zone plus any of—tenderness at posterior edge/tip of lateral or medial malleolus (distal 6 cm), or inability to bear weight for 4 steps immediately and in the ED. ([aci.health.nsw.gov.au](https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-ankle-adult?utm_source=openai))

Ottawa Knee Rule
- Knee X‑ray if any: age ≥55, isolated patellar tenderness, fibular head tenderness, inability to flex to 90°, or inability to bear weight for 4 steps immediately and in the ED. ([aci.health.nsw.gov.au](https://aci.health.nsw.gov.au/ecat/appendices/ottawa-knee?utm_source=openai))

response:

question: What is the SOFA score composition, and how is it used in sepsis?
response:
Composition: Six organ systems, each scored 0–4 points:
- Respiratory (PaO2/FiO2)
- Coagulation (platelets)
- Liver (bilirubin)
- Cardiovascular (MAP and need/dose of vasopressors)
- Central nervous system (Glasgow Coma Scale)
- Renal (creatinine or urine output)
Total score 0–24.

Use in sepsis: Sepsis-3 (2016) defines sepsis as life‑threatening organ dysfunction from infection, operationalized as an acute increase in SOFA ≥2 points from baseline, which corresponds to an in‑hospital mortality generally >10%. If prior organ dysfunction is unknown, baseline is assumed zero. SOFA is used to identify organ dysfunction, trend severity over time, and risk‑stratify; higher or rising scores indicate worse prognosis.

Sources:
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8204681/
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9824069/

question: What is the SOFA score composition, and how is it used in sepsis?
response:
Composition: SOFA scores six organ systems, each 0–4 points: respiratory (PaO2/FiO2, with consideration of mechanical ventilation), coagulation (platelet count), liver (bilirubin), cardiovascular (MAP and vasopressor dose), central nervous system (Glasgow Coma Scale), and renal (creatinine or urine output); total 0–24. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2703722/?utm_source=openai))

Use in sepsis: Sepsis-3 defines sepsis as life‑threatening organ dysfunction due to infection, operationalized as an acute increase in SOFA ≥2 from baseline; higher and rising SOFA scores indicate greater mortality risk and are trended serially. Septic shock is a subset requiring vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mm Hg and lactate >2 mmol/L after fluids. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2703722/

question: What is the SOFA score composition, and how is it used in sepsis?
response:
Composition: SOFA sums six organ-system subscores (0–4 each): respiratory (PaO2/FiO2), coagulation (platelets), liver (bilirubin), cardiovascular (MAP/vasopressors), neurologic (Glasgow Coma Scale), and renal (creatinine or urine output); total 0–24. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4140959/?utm_source=openai))
Use in sepsis: Sepsis‑3 defines sepsis as suspected/confirmed infection plus an acute SOFA increase ≥2 points; clinicians use SOFA to identify organ dysfunction, stratify risk, and track course, as serial changes correlate with mortality. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881?utm_source=openai))

Source relevance: JAMA 2016 provides the consensus definition linking SOFA to sepsis, the PMC article shows the SOFA components, and the JAMA study validates serial SOFA for prognosis. ([jamanetwork.com](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4140959/
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11594901/

question: What is the SOFA score composition, and how is it used in sepsis?
response:
Composition (six organ systems; each scored 0–4, total 0–24):
- Respiratory: PaO2/FiO2 ratio (considering respiratory support).
- Coagulation: Platelet count.
- Liver: Serum bilirubin.
- Cardiovascular: Mean arterial pressure and vasopressor dose.
- Central nervous system: Glasgow Coma Scale.
- Renal: Serum creatinine or urine output.

Use in sepsis:
- Sepsis-3 defines sepsis as suspected or documented infection plus an acute increase in SOFA ≥2 from baseline; this associates with >10% in-hospital mortality. It is used to quantify organ dysfunction, risk-stratify patients, and track trajectory. Septic shock is sepsis with vasopressors needed to keep MAP ≥65 mm Hg and lactate >2 mmol/L despite fluids (mortality >40%). 

Sources:
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2492881
https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/multimedia/table/sequential-organ-failure-assessment-sofa-score

question: What are the ABCDE warning signs of melanoma?
response:
The ABCDE warning signs of melanoma:
- Asymmetry: one half unlike the other.
- Border: irregular, scalloped, or poorly defined.
- Color: multiple/uneven colors; may include white, red, or blue.
- Diameter: usually >6 mm (~¼ inch), but can be smaller.
- Evolving: any change or new symptoms (itching, bleeding, crusting).

See a dermatologist promptly for any concerning spot. ([aad.org](https://www.aad.org/public/diseases/skin-cancer/types/common/melanoma/symptoms?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.aad.org/public/diseases/skin-cancer/types/common/melanoma/symptoms
https://www.cdc.gov/skin-cancer/symptoms/index.html
https://www.cancer.gov/types/skin/melanoma-photos

question: What are the ABCDE warning signs of melanoma?
response:
The ABCDE warning signs of melanoma:
- A – Asymmetry: one half doesn’t match the other.
- B – Border: edges are irregular, ragged, notched, or blurred.
- C – Color: uneven color or multiple colors (brown/black; sometimes red, white, or blue).
- D – Diameter: larger than 6 mm (¼ inch), though melanomas can be smaller.
- E – Evolving: any change (size, shape, or color) or new symptoms like itching or bleeding.

If you notice any of these features, get the spot checked by a clinician promptly.

Sources:
https://www.aad.org/media/stats/conditions/melanoma-faqs
https://www.cancer.org/cancer/types/melanoma-skin-cancer/detection-diagnosis-staging/signs-and-symptoms.html

question: What are the ABCDE warning signs of melanoma?
response:
ABCDE warning signs of melanoma:
- Asymmetry: one half doesn’t match the other.
- Border: irregular, ragged, scalloped, or poorly defined edges.
- Color: uneven colors (shades of brown/black; sometimes white, red, or blue).
- Diameter: usually >6 mm (about a pencil eraser), though melanomas can be smaller.
- Evolving: any change in size, shape, color, or symptoms. ([aad.org](https://www.aad.org/public/spot-skin-cancer/learn-about-skin-cancer/detect/how-to-spot-skin-cancer/how-to-spot-skin-cancer?utm_source=openai))

These criteria come from the American Academy of Dermatology and the CDC, authoritative clinical/public-health sources on melanoma detection. ([aad.org](https://www.aad.org/public/spot-skin-cancer/learn-about-skin-cancer/detect/how-to-spot-skin-cancer/how-to-spot-skin-cancer?utm_source=openai))

question: What are the ABCDE warning signs of melanoma?
response:
The ABCDE warning signs of melanoma:
- A – Asymmetry: one half doesn’t match the other.
- B – Border: irregular, ragged, or blurred edges.
- C – Color: uneven color or multiple shades.
- D – Diameter: larger than 6 mm (about ¼ inch) or increasing in size.
- E – Evolving: any change in size, shape, color, or new symptoms (itching, bleeding). ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/skin-cancer/symptoms/index.html?utm_source=openai))

Note: Some melanomas are smaller than 6 mm and don’t meet all criteria—have any changing or unusual spot checked promptly. ([cancer.org](https://www.cancer.org/cancer/types/melanoma-skin-cancer/detection-diagnosis-staging/signs-and-symptoms.html?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/skin-cancer/symptoms/index.html
https://www.cancer.org/cancer/types/melanoma-skin-cancer/detection-diagnosis-staging/signs-and-symptoms.html

question: What are the normal ranges for PR, QRS, and QTc intervals on ECG?
response:
- PR interval: 120–200 ms (0.12–0.20 s). ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/pr-interval-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))
- QRS duration: typically 70–100 ms (up to 110 ms may be normal); “wide” if ≥120 ms. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/qrs-interval-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))
- QTc (rate-corrected QT):
  - Men: normal <440 ms; Women: normal <460 ms.
  - Markedly prolonged if >500 ms; abnormally short if <350 ms. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/qt-interval-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))

Notes: Large population data place 2nd–98th percentile reference ranges at PR 113–212 ms, QRS 69–109 ms, and QTc (Bazett) 361–457 ms. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17276451/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://litfl.com/pr-interval-ecg-library/
https://litfl.com/qrs-interval-ecg-library/
https://litfl.com/qt-interval-ecg-library/
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17276451/

question: What are the normal ranges for PR, QRS, and QTc intervals on ECG?
response:
- PR interval: 0.12–0.20 s (120–200 ms). ([merckmanuals.com](https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/cardiovascular-tests-and-procedures/electrocardiography))
- QRS duration: 0.07–0.10 s (70–100 ms); ≥0.12 s is considered wide. ([merckmanuals.com](https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/cardiovascular-tests-and-procedures/electrocardiography))
- QTc (rate-corrected): Men ~350–450 ms; Women ~360–460 ms (adults). ([merckmanuals.com](https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/cardiovascular-tests-and-procedures/electrocardiography))

response:
- PR interval: 120–200 ms.
- QRS duration: <120 ms (usually 60–100 ms).
- QTc: ≤440 ms (men) and ≤460 ms (women). ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK549803/?utm_source=openai))

question: What are the normal ranges for PR, QRS, and QTc intervals on ECG?
response:
Normal adult ECG intervals:
- PR: 120–200 ms (0.12–0.20 s). ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/pr-interval-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))
- QRS: typically 70–100 ms; up to 110 ms may be seen in healthy adults; clinical upper limit of normal is <120 ms. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/qrs-interval-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))
- QTc (rate-corrected QT): Men <450 ms; Women <460 ms. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/qt-interval-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))

Notes: QTc depends on the correction formula (e.g., Bazett, Fridericia); risk rises notably when QTc ≥500 ms. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/qt-interval-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))

question: What are first-line drug classes for initial hypertension management in adults?
response:
First-line antihypertensive drug classes for most adults:
- Thiazide/thiazide-like diuretics (prefer chlorthalidone).
- ACE inhibitors.
- ARBs.
- Calcium channel blockers. ([acc.org](https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2017/11/09/11/41/2017-Guideline-for-High-Blood-Pressure-in-Adults?utm_source=openai))

Notes:
- In Black adults without CKD/HF, start with a thiazide or CCB. 
- Beta-blockers are not first line unless there’s a compelling indication (e.g., CAD or HFrEF). 
- Avoid combining an ACE inhibitor with an ARB. ([acc.org](https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2017/11/09/11/41/2017-Guideline-for-High-Blood-Pressure-in-Adults?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
```
https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2017/11/09/11/41/2017-Guideline-for-High-Blood-Pressure-in-Adults
https://www.ccjm.org/content/85/10/771
https://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/articles/2017/11/14/14/42/the-2017-high-blood-pressure-guideline-risk-reduction-through-better-management
```

question: What is the difference between unstable angina and NSTEMI?
response:
Key difference: myocardial injury.

- Biomarkers: NSTEMI shows a rise/fall of cardiac troponin above the 99th percentile (evidence of necrosis). Unstable angina has ischemic symptoms but troponin remains below the 99th percentile (no acute injury).
- ECG: Neither has persistent ST elevation; both may have ST depression/T‑wave inversion or be normal.
- Pathophysiology: NSTEMI = infarction; unstable angina = ischemia without infarction.
- Prognosis: NSTEMI carries higher short‑term mortality; unstable angina is lower risk but still serious.
- Trends/management: High‑sensitivity troponins have reclassified many cases from unstable angina to NSTEMI. Both are NSTE‑ACS; NSTEMI more often benefits from early invasive strategies, while unstable angina management is risk‑guided.

Sources:
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/44/38/3720/7243210
https://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2018/08/24/00/09/fourth-universal-definition-of-mi-esc-2018
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8026278/
https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/coronary-artery-disease/unstable-angina

question: What is the difference between unstable angina and NSTEMI?
response:
Both are non–ST-elevation acute coronary syndromes. The key distinction is myocardial necrosis: NSTEMI has elevated cardiac troponin (above the 99th‑percentile upper reference limit) with a rise/fall pattern consistent with ischemia; unstable angina has ischemic symptoms/signs but troponins remain normal or below MI criteria. ([acc.org](https://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/articles/2018/11/16/09/06/fourth-universal-definition-of-mi?utm_source=openai))
ECG may be normal or show transient ST depression/T‑wave inversion in either condition. ([merckmanuals.com](https://www.merckmanuals.com/en-ca/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/coronary-artery-disease/overview-of-acute-coronary-syndromes-acs?utm_source=openai))
Clinical approach overlaps (antiplatelets, anticoagulation, and early invasive evaluation based on risk), but NSTEMI generally carries higher short‑term risk and is treated as myocardial infarction. With high‑sensitivity troponin assays, many cases once labeled “unstable angina” are now reclassified as NSTEMI. ([escardio.org](https://www.escardio.org/Guidelines/Clinical-Practice-Guidelines/Acute-Coronary-Syndromes-ACS-Guidelines?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/articles/2018/11/16/09/06/fourth-universal-definition-of-mi
https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/coronary-artery-disease/overview-of-acute-coronary-syndromes-acs
https://www.escardio.org/Guidelines/Clinical-Practice-Guidelines/Acute-Coronary-Syndromes-ACS-Guidelines

question: What is the difference between unstable angina and NSTEMI?
response:
- Both conditions are non–ST-elevation acute coronary syndromes. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/42/14/1289/5898842?utm_source=openai))
- NSTEMI: ischemic symptoms plus a rise/fall in cardiac troponin indicating acute cardiomyocyte necrosis. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8026278/?utm_source=openai))
- Unstable angina: ischemic symptoms at rest or minimal exertion without troponin elevation (no myocardial necrosis). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8026278/?utm_source=openai))
- Prognosis/management: NSTEMI carries higher short‑term mortality; unstable angina patients are lower risk and derive less benefit from aggressive pharmacologic/invasive strategies. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/42/14/1289/5898842?utm_source=openai))

Source relevance: The 2020 ESC guideline and its companion Q&A explicitly define NSTEMI vs unstable angina by troponin/necrosis and outline their differing risks, with ACC summaries reinforcing these points.

Sources:
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/42/14/1289/5898842
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8026278/
https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2020/08/28/20/42/2020-ESC-Guidelines-for-Acute-Coronary-Syndromes-ESC-2020

question: What is the difference between unstable angina and NSTEMI?
response:
Key differences
- Biomarkers/pathology: NSTEMI = myocardial necrosis with a rise/fall in cardiac troponin above the 99th percentile; unstable angina (UA) = ischemia without biomarker elevation (no rise/fall), hence no necrosis.
- ECG: Both are non–ST-elevation ACS; may show ST depression or T‑wave inversion (or be normal). No persistent ST elevation.
- Prognosis: NSTEMI generally carries higher short‑term mortality and risk than UA.
- Management: Both receive anti‑ischemic and antithrombotic therapy. Early invasive strategy is prioritized for NSTEMI or high‑risk features; routine aggressive invasion benefits UA less.
- Note: With high‑sensitivity troponin testing, many cases once labeled UA are now classified as NSTEMI.

Sources:
https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2018/08/24/00/09/Fourth-Universal-Definition-of-MI-ESC-2018
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513228/
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK442000/
https://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2020/08/28/20/42/2020-esc-guidelines-for-acute-coronary-syndromes-esc-2020
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25820165/

question: What red-flag findings in acute headache mandate emergent neuroimaging?
response:
Emergent neuroimaging is warranted for acute headache with any of the following:
- Thunderclap onset (sudden, maximal within minutes), including with exertion/sex/Valsalva. ([nice.org.uk](https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng228/chapter/Recommendations))
- New focal neurologic deficit, altered mental status, or first seizure. ([hopkinsmedicine.org](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache))
- Papilledema or other signs of raised intracranial pressure. ([hopkinsmedicine.org](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache))
- Fever, neck stiffness, immunosuppression, or suspected CNS infection. ([hopkinsmedicine.org](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache))
- Head trauma or anticoagulation/bleeding risk. ([hopkinsmedicine.org](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache))
- New headache in pregnancy or postpartum (e.g., CVT, RCVS, preeclampsia). ([americanheadachesociety.org](https://americanheadachesociety.org/research/library/red-flags-in-headache-what-if-it-isnt-migraine))
- Known cancer or HIV/immunocompromise with new headache. ([hopkinsmedicine.org](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache))
- New-onset after age 50 or substantial change/progression in pattern. ([americanheadachesociety.org](https://americanheadachesociety.org/research/library/red-flags-in-headache-what-if-it-isnt-migraine))
- Positional headache or one triggered by cough/exertion. ([hopkinsmedicine.org](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache))

These align with SNOOP/SNNOOP10 red flags; for suspected hemorrhage, start with noncontrast head CT and follow ACEP guidance for LP/CTA when indicated. ([acep.org](https://www.acep.org/patient-care/clinical-policies/headache))

Sources:
https://www.acep.org/patient-care/clinical-policies/headache
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31543134/
https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache
https://americanheadachesociety.org/research/library/red-flags-in-headache-what-if-it-isnt-migraine
https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng228/chapter/Recommendations

question: What red-flag findings in acute headache mandate emergent neuroimaging?
response:
Emergent neuroimaging is indicated for acute headache with any of these red flags:
- Thunderclap onset or onset with exertion/sex/cough.
- Focal neurologic deficit, new seizure, or altered mental status.
- Papilledema or signs of increased intracranial pressure.
- Fever/meningismus or suspected CNS infection; immunocompromise or known cancer.
- Head trauma.
- New headache in pregnancy/postpartum (preeclampsia risk).
- New or progressive headache at age ≥50 (consider temporal arteritis).
- Positional headache or marked change from prior pattern (“worst ever”).

These features warrant urgent CT and/or MRI based on scenario per ACEP clinical policy and ACR Appropriateness Criteria; Hopkins summarizes practical red flags. ([acep.org](https://www.acep.org/patient-care/clinical-policies/headache))

Sources:
https://www.acep.org/patient-care/clinical-policies/headache
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37236753/
https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache

question: What red-flag findings in acute headache mandate emergent neuroimaging?
response:
Red flags mandating emergent neuroimaging:
- Thunderclap or abrupt maximal-onset headache (including exertional/sexual). 
- New focal neurologic deficit or altered mental status. 
- Papilledema or other signs of raised intracranial pressure. 
- Fever, meningismus, or systemic infection; immunocompromised state. 
- New headache in patients with cancer or HIV. 
- New or progressive headache after age >50. 
- Pregnancy or postpartum. 
- Headache after head trauma. 
- Positional headache or triggered by cough/Valsalva. 
- Ocular pain/red eye suggesting acute angle-closure glaucoma. 
In the ED, noncontrast head CT is first-line; add LP or CTA if SAH risk persists. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37236753/?utm_source=openai))

These sources are current ED policy and imaging guidelines plus a peer‑reviewed primary‑care review that enumerate headache red flags and specify when emergent CT/MRI (and LP/CTA for suspected SAH) is indicated.

Sources:
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37236753/
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36126007/
https://www.acep.org/patient-care/clinical-policies/headache

question: What red-flag findings in acute headache mandate emergent neuroimaging?
response:
Red flags that mandate emergent neuroimaging in acute headache:
- Thunderclap/worst-ever onset or onset with exertion/sex/Valsalva. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36126007/?utm_source=openai))
- New focal neurologic deficit, altered mental status, or new seizure. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36126007/?utm_source=openai))
- Papilledema or other signs of raised intracranial pressure. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36126007/?utm_source=openai))
- Fever/meningismus with concern for CNS infection; in suspected meningitis, get head CT before LP if immunocompromised, new seizure, focal deficit, papilledema, or altered consciousness. ([ccjm.org](https://www.ccjm.org/content/84/2/111?utm_source=openai))
- New headache in cancer or immunocompromised, pregnancy/postpartum, age >50 with new or rapidly worsening pattern, recent head trauma, or suspected cervical artery dissection (neck pain/Horner). ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24933450/?utm_source=openai))

Initial ED test is noncontrast head CT for suspected hemorrhage/mass; MRI is preferred for other concerning features. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36126007/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36126007/
https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/imaging/provider-information/order-wisely/headache
https://www.acep.org/patient-care/clinical-policies/headache
https://www.ccjm.org/content/84/2/111
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24933450/

question: What is the first-line acute treatment for ischemic stroke within the thrombolysis window?
response:
Intravenous thrombolysis with alteplase (tPA) is first-line for eligible acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of last-known-well. Standard dose: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), give 10% as an IV bolus over 1 minute, then infuse the remainder over 60 minutes after hemorrhage is excluded on imaging. 

Note: Many guidelines now accept tenecteplase 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus as a reasonable alternative to alteplase in the <4.5‑hour window, particularly when large-vessel occlusion is suspected and thrombectomy is planned.

Sources:
https://professional.heart.org/en/science-news/2019-update-to-the-2018-acute-ischemic-stroke-guidelines
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499977/
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37021186/
https://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2019/11/06/15/31/guidelines-for-the-early-management-of-ais

question: What is the first-line acute treatment for ischemic stroke within the thrombolysis window?
response:
Intravenous thrombolysis with alteplase (tPA) is first-line for eligible acute ischemic stroke within the thrombolysis window: ideally ≤3 hours from last known well, and for selected patients up to 4.5 hours. Standard dose: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), 10% IV bolus, remainder over 60 minutes. Tenecteplase 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus is a guideline-supported alternative and has been shown noninferior to alteplase in randomized trials, especially reasonable when bridging to thrombectomy.

Sources:
https://professional.heart.org/en/science-news/2019-update-to-the-2018-acute-ischemic-stroke-guidelines/top-things-to-know
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2823655

question: What is the first-line acute treatment for ischemic stroke within the thrombolysis window?
response:
Intravenous thrombolysis—IV alteplase (tPA) 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg) started as soon as possible within 4.5 hours of onset after excluding hemorrhage; IV tenecteplase 0.25 mg/kg is an evidence-based alternative in this window.

Why these sources: AHA/ASA guidelines designate IV alteplase as standard therapy within 4.5 hours, and ESO’s expedited recommendation plus recent RCT evidence support tenecteplase 0.25 mg/kg as a safe, effective alternative.

question: What is the first-line acute treatment for ischemic stroke within the thrombolysis window?
response:
Intravenous thrombolysis—specifically alteplase (rt‑PA)—is first‑line. Dose: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), give 10% as an IV bolus then infuse the remainder over 60 minutes. Start as soon as possible within 4.5 hours after symptom onset once intracranial hemorrhage is excluded. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31662117/?utm_source=openai))

Tenecteplase 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus is an acceptable alternative in many systems (ESO favors it for large‑vessel occlusion candidates; ACEP allows either agent). ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37021186/?utm_source=openai))

question: What are standard infection-control precautions (contact, droplet, airborne) and when are they used?
response:
These are transmission‑based precautions used with Standard Precautions.

- Contact: for pathogens spread by touch/fomites. Wear gloves and gown on entry; dedicate equipment; single room if possible. Examples: C. difficile, MRSA, scabies, draining wounds/diarrhea. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))
- Droplet: for large respiratory droplets. Wear a surgical mask on entry; mask patient during transport. Examples: influenza, pertussis, meningococcal disease, mumps, rubella. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))
- Airborne: for pathogens that remain suspended in air. Place in an airborne infection isolation room (negative pressure) and wear a fit‑tested N95 or higher; mask patient for transport. Examples: tuberculosis, measles, varicella/disseminated zoster. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html
https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/isolation-precautions/appendix-a-type-duration.html
https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/isolation-precautions/glossary.html

question: What are standard infection-control precautions (contact, droplet, airborne) and when are they used?
response:
These are Transmission-Based Precautions, used in addition to Standard Precautions when a pathogen’s route of spread requires extra measures. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))

- Contact: For germs spread by direct touch or contaminated surfaces. Wear gloves and gown on room entry; use dedicated equipment; single room if possible. Typical uses: C. difficile, MRSA, norovirus. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))
- Droplet: For pathogens carried in respiratory droplets during coughing/sneezing/talking. Don a medical/surgical mask on entry; mask the patient for transport; single room if available. Typical uses: influenza, pertussis, meningococcal disease. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))
- Airborne: For infectious aerosols that remain suspended. Place patient in an airborne infection isolation room (negative pressure); staff use fit-tested N95 (or higher). Typical uses: tuberculosis, measles, varicella. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html
https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/isolation-precautions/appendix-a.html

question: What are standard infection-control precautions (contact, droplet, airborne) and when are they used?
response:
Transmission-Based Precautions (used in addition to Standard Precautions) are: ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html))
- Contact: Prevents spread via direct/indirect contact with the patient or environment; wear gloves and gown on entry; use for suspected/confirmed infections with high contact transmission risk (e.g., heavy drainage, fecal incontinence). ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html))
- Droplet: Prevents spread via respiratory droplets from coughing/sneezing/talking; mask on entry and mask the patient for source control; use when a droplet-transmitted infection is suspected/confirmed. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html))
- Airborne: Prevents spread of pathogens that remain suspended; place patient in an AIIR and use a fit-tested N95 or higher; used for tuberculosis, measles, and chickenpox/disseminated zoster. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html))

Source relevance: CDC’s Transmission-Based Precautions page summarizes definitions, indications, required PPE, and example diseases for contact, droplet, and airborne precautions. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html))

Sources:
https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html

question: What are standard infection-control precautions (contact, droplet, airborne) and when are they used?
response:
Contact, Droplet, and Airborne are Transmission-Based Precautions used in addition to Standard Precautions. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))

- Standard Precautions: For all patients; hand hygiene; risk-based PPE (gloves, gown, mask/eye protection); respiratory hygiene/cough etiquette; safe injections; cleaning and equipment reprocessing. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/standard-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))
- Contact: For touch-borne pathogens; gown and gloves on entry; dedicated/disinfected equipment. Examples: C. difficile, norovirus (gastroenteritis), draining wounds/MRSA, scabies. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))
- Droplet: For large respiratory droplets; surgical mask on entry; mask patient for transport. Examples: influenza, pertussis, meningococcal disease. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))
- Airborne: For aerosols; fit-tested N95 (or higher) and an airborne infection isolation room. Examples: tuberculosis, measles, varicella. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/hcp/basics/transmission-based-precautions.html?utm_source=openai))

question: What are common red flags in chest pain that suggest ACS?
response:
Common ACS red flags in chest pain
- Pressure-like chest discomfort ± radiation to arm, jaw, neck, or back.
- Exertional or occurring at rest; lasts >15–20 minutes or has a new/crescendo pattern.
- Associated dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea/vomiting, or syncope.
- Abnormal vitals (hypotension, tachycardia), new heart failure signs or new murmur.
- Ischemic ECG changes (ST elevation/depression, T‑wave inversion/new LBBB) or positive troponin.
- High-risk context: known CAD/prior MI, diabetes, smoking; stimulant (e.g., cocaine) use.
- Anginal equivalents (epigastric discomfort, isolated dyspnea, unusual fatigue), especially in women, older adults, and people with diabetes. ([professional.heart.org](https://professional.heart.org/en/science-news/2021-guideline-for-the-evaluation-and-diagnosis-of-chest-pain?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://professional.heart.org/en/science-news/2021-guideline-for-the-evaluation-and-diagnosis-of-chest-pain
https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg95/chapter/Recommendations
https://www.aafp.org/pubs/afp/issues/2023/0200/practice-guidelines-chest-pain-evaluation.html

question: What are common red flags in chest pain that suggest ACS?
response:
Common ACS red flags in chest pain:
- Pressure/tightness/heaviness, possibly radiating to arm, jaw, or back.
- Rest or minimal‑exertion onset; new/crescendo pattern; prolonged (>15–20 min).
- Dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea/vomiting, or syncope.
- Hemodynamic instability (hypotension, arrhythmia), new heart failure/pulmonary edema, or new murmur.
- ECG: ST‑elevation or presumed new LBBB; dynamic ST‑depression/T‑wave inversion.
- Positive or rising high‑sensitivity troponin.
- High‑risk history: known CAD, prior MI/revascularization, or multiple cardiac risk factors.

Key references supporting these features. ([nice.org.uk](https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg95/chapter/Recommendations?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg95/chapter/Recommendations
https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2021/10/27/14/06/2021-Guideline-for-Chest-Pain-gl_chestpain

question: What are common red flags in chest pain that suggest ACS?
response:
Common red flags for ACS in a patient with chest pain:
- Prolonged chest pressure/tightness (>15–20 minutes), or new/worsening, frequent recurrent episodes with little exertion. ([nice.org.uk](https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg95/chapter/Recommendations?utm_source=openai))
- Pain radiating to arm(s), jaw, neck, or back with associated breathlessness, marked sweating, or nausea/vomiting. ([nice.org.uk](https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg95/chapter/Recommendations?utm_source=openai))
- Hemodynamic instability (e.g., hypotension). ([nice.org.uk](https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg95/chapter/Recommendations?utm_source=openai))
- High‑risk ECG findings (ST elevation/depression, new LBBB) or elevated high‑sensitivity troponin. ([aafp.org](https://www.aafp.org/pubs/afp/issues/2023/0200/practice-guidelines-chest-pain-evaluation.html?utm_source=openai))

Source relevance: NICE CG95 explicitly lists symptom/instability features that indicate ACS; the 2021 AHA/ACC chest pain guideline outlines ischemic symptom patterns and prioritizes ECG/troponin; AAFP summarizes high‑risk ECG changes in suspected cardiac chest pain.

question: What are common red flags in chest pain that suggest ACS?
response:
Red flags suggesting ACS:
- Chest pressure/heaviness/tightness at rest or with exertion, lasting >10–20 minutes, recurrent/worsening, or radiating to arm(s), neck, jaw, back.
- Associated symptoms: dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea/vomiting, lightheadedness/syncope.
- High-risk history: age >50, known CAD or prior MI/PCI/CABG, diabetes, smoking, strong family history, or cocaine use.
- Abnormal vitals/exam: hypotension, tachy- or bradyarrhythmia, new heart failure signs (rales, S3), or new murmur.
- ECG changes: ST elevation/depression, new T‑wave inversions, new LBBB, or posterior ischemia.
- Positive/rising high‑sensitivity troponin.

These features warrant immediate ED evaluation for possible ACS. ([acc.org](https://www.acc.org/Latest-in-Cardiology/ten-points-to-remember/2021/10/27/14/06/2021-Guideline-for-Chest-Pain-gl_chestpain?utm_source=openai))
